notes.title: Angular Basics - Setup & Installation
notes.content:
Angular Setup Guide

Prerequisites

  • Node.js - Download from nodejs.org
  • npm - Comes with Node.js
  • VS Code - Code editor

Installation Steps

  1. Install Angular CLI:
    npm install -g @angular/cli
  2. Check version:
    ng version
  3. Create new project:
    ng new my-app
  4. Run the app:
    cd my-app
npm start

Important Commands

ng serve - Start development server

ng build - Build for production

ng generate component - Create new component

ng test - Run unit tests

Common Issues

⚠️ Port already in use:

ng serve --port 4500

⚠️ Permission denied: Run terminal as Administrator

notes.title: JavaScript ES6+ Features
notes.content:
Modern JavaScript ES6+ Features

1. Arrow Functions

Syntax: const func = () => {}

const add = (a, b) => a + b;
const greet = name => `Hello ${name}`;

// Lexical 'this' binding
class Person {
  constructor() {
    this.age = 0;
    setInterval(() => {
      this.age++; // 'this' refers to Person instance
    }, 1000);
  }
}

2. Destructuring

// Object Destructuring
const person = { name: 'John', age: 25, city: 'NYC' };
const { name, age } = person;

// Array Destructuring
const colors = ['red', 'green', 'blue'];
const [primary, secondary] = colors;

3. Spread Operator

// Array spread
const arr1 = [1, 2, 3];
const arr2 = [...arr1, 4, 5]; // [1, 2, 3, 4, 5]

// Object spread
const obj1 = { a: 1, b: 2 };
const obj2 = { ...obj1, c: 3 }; // { a: 1, b: 2, c: 3 }

4. Template Literals

const name = 'John';
const age = 25;
const message = `Hello ${name}, you are ${age} years old`;

// Multiline strings
const html = `
  <div>
    <h1>${name}</h1>
  </div>
`;

5. Promises & Async/Await

// Promises
fetch('https://api.example.com/data')
  .then(res => res.json())
  .then(data => console.log(data))
  .catch(err => console.error(err));

// Async/Await
async function fetchData() {
  try {
    const response = await fetch('https://api.example.com/data');
    const data = await response.json();
    return data;
  } catch (error) {
    console.error(error);
  }
}

6. Classes

class Person {
  constructor(name, age) {
    this.name = name;
    this.age = age;
  }

  greet() {
    return `Hello, I'm ${this.name}`;
  }
}

class Employee extends Person {
  constructor(name, age, role) {
    super(name, age);
    this.role = role;
  }
}

notes.title: Angular Component Lifecycle Hooks
notes.content:
Angular Lifecycle Hooks Complete Guide

What are Lifecycle Hooks?

Angular creates, updates, and destroys components during runtime. Lifecycle hooks are methods that allow you to tap into these key moments.

1. ngOnChanges

When: Before ngOnInit and whenever @Input properties change

ngOnChanges(changes: SimpleChanges) {
  console.log('Input changed:', changes);
  if (changes['data']) {
    // React to data input change
  }
}

Use Cases: React to input changes, validation

2. ngOnInit ⭐ (Most Used)

When: After first ngOnChanges, once component is initialized

ngOnInit() {
  this.loadData();
  this.subscribeToEvents();
}

Use Cases: Initialize data, API calls, subscriptions

3. ngDoCheck

When: During every change detection run

ngDoCheck() {
  // Custom change detection
}

Use Cases: Custom change detection logic (use carefully, impacts performance)

4. ngAfterContentInit

When: After ng-content is projected

ngAfterContentInit() {
  console.log('Content projected');
}

5. ngAfterViewInit

When: After component's view is initialized

@ViewChild('childComponent') child!: ChildComponent;

ngAfterViewInit() {
  this.child.doSomething();
}

Use Cases: Access ViewChild, DOM manipulation

6. ngOnDestroy ⭐ (Important)

When: Just before component is destroyed

private subscription: Subscription;

ngOnDestroy() {
  this.subscription.unsubscribe();
  clearInterval(this.timer);
}

Use Cases: Cleanup - unsubscribe observables, clear timers, prevent memory leaks

Lifecycle Order

  1. constructor
  2. ngOnChanges
  3. ngOnInit
  4. ngDoCheck
  5. ngAfterContentInit
  6. ngAfterContentChecked
  7. ngAfterViewInit
  8. ngAfterViewChecked
  9. ngOnDestroy

notes.title: TypeScript Interview Questions
notes.content:
TypeScript Important Concepts

1. What is TypeScript?

TypeScript is a superset of JavaScript that adds static typing. It compiles to plain JavaScript.

Benefits:

  • Type safety
  • Better IDE support
  • Early error detection
  • Improved code maintainability

2. Types in TypeScript

// Primitive Types
let name: string = 'John';
let age: number = 25;
let isActive: boolean = true;

// Array Types
let numbers: number[] = [1, 2, 3];
let names: Array<string> = ['Alice', 'Bob'];

// Tuple
let person: [string, number] = ['John', 25];

// Enum
enum Color { Red, Green, Blue }
let c: Color = Color.Green;

// Any (avoid using)
let data: any = 'can be anything';

// Union Types
let id: string | number = 123;

3. Interfaces vs Types

// Interface
interface User {
  name: string;
  age: number;
  email?: string; // Optional
}

// Type Alias
type Product = {
  id: number;
  title: string;
  price: number;
};

4. Access Modifiers

  • public - Accessible everywhere (default)
  • private - Only within the class
  • protected - Within class and subclasses
class Employee {
  public name: string;
  private salary: number;
  protected department: string;
}

5. Generics

function identity<T>(arg: T): T {
  return arg;
}

let output = identity<string>('Hello');

// Generic Interface
interface Response<T> {
  data: T;
  status: number;
}

const userResponse: Response<User> = {
  data: { name: 'John', age: 25 },
  status: 200
};

Key Interview Points

✅ TypeScript provides compile-time type checking

✅ It's not a separate language, just JavaScript with types

✅ Helps catch bugs during development, not runtime

✅ All JavaScript code is valid TypeScript

notes.title: RxJS Operators Guide
notes.content:
RxJS Operators - Essential Guide

What is RxJS?

RxJS (Reactive Extensions for JavaScript) is a library for reactive programming using Observables, making it easier to compose asynchronous code.

Transformation Operators

1. map

import { map } from 'rxjs/operators';

this.http.get<User[]>('/api/users')
  .pipe(
    map(users => users.map(u => ({ ...u, fullName: `${u.firstName} ${u.lastName}` })))
  )
  .subscribe(users => console.log(users));

2. switchMap

Cancel previous, use latest

this.searchControl.valueChanges
  .pipe(
    debounceTime(300),
    switchMap(term => this.http.get(`/api/search?q=${term}`))
  )
  .subscribe(results => this.results = results);

3. mergeMap

Execute all in parallel

const ids = [1, 2, 3];
from(ids).pipe(
  mergeMap(id => this.http.get(`/api/user/${id}`))
).subscribe(user => console.log(user));

4. concatMap

Execute sequentially

from(requests).pipe(
  concatMap(req => this.http.post('/api/data', req))
).subscribe();

Filtering Operators

1. filter

fromEvent(document, 'click')
  .pipe(
    filter((event: any) => event.target.tagName === 'BUTTON')
  )
  .subscribe(event => console.log('Button clicked'));

2. debounceTime

this.searchInput.valueChanges
  .pipe(
    debounceTime(500),
    distinctUntilChanged()
  )
  .subscribe(value => this.search(value));

3. take

// Take first 5 emissions
this.dataStream$.pipe(
  take(5)
).subscribe(data => console.log(data));

4. takeUntil

private destroy$ = new Subject();

ngOnInit() {
  this.dataService.getData()
    .pipe(takeUntil(this.destroy$))
    .subscribe(data => this.data = data);
}

ngOnDestroy() {
  this.destroy$.next();
  this.destroy$.complete();
}

Error Handling

catchError

import { catchError } from 'rxjs/operators';
import { of } from 'rxjs';

this.http.get('/api/data')
  .pipe(
    catchError(error => {
      console.error('Error:', error);
      return of([]);  // Return empty array as fallback
    })
  )
  .subscribe(data => console.log(data));

Combination Operators

combineLatest

combineLatest([
  this.userService.getUser(),
  this.settingsService.getSettings()
]).subscribe(([user, settings]) => {
  console.log('User:', user);
  console.log('Settings:', settings);
});

Utility Operators

tap

this.http.get('/api/data')
  .pipe(
    tap(data => console.log('Data received:', data)),
    map(data => data.items)
  )
  .subscribe(items => console.log(items));

notes.title: Git Commands Essentials
notes.content:
Git Commands - Developer's Guide

Basic Commands

Initialize & Clone

# Initialize new repository
git init

# Clone existing repository
git clone https://github.com/username/repo.git

Status & Changes

# Check status
git status

# View changes
git diff

# View commit history
git log --oneline --graph

Staging & Committing

# Stage all files
git add .

# Stage specific file
git add filename.txt

# Commit with message
git commit -m "Your commit message"

# Add and commit in one command
git commit -am "Message"

Branching

# List branches
git branch

# Create new branch
git branch feature-login

# Switch to branch
git checkout feature-login

# Create and switch (shortcut)
git checkout -b feature-login

# Delete branch
git branch -d feature-login

Remote Operations

# Push to remote
git push origin main

# Pull from remote
git pull origin main

# Fetch changes without merging
git fetch origin

# View remotes
git remote -v

Merging

# Merge branch into current
git merge feature-login

# Abort merge if conflicts
git merge --abort

Undoing Changes

# Unstage file
git reset HEAD filename.txt

# Discard changes in working directory
git checkout -- filename.txt

# Undo last commit (keep changes)
git reset --soft HEAD~1

# Undo last commit (discard changes)
git reset --hard HEAD~1

# Revert commit (creates new commit)
git revert commit-hash

Stashing

# Stash changes
git stash

# List stashes
git stash list

# Apply latest stash
git stash apply

# Apply and remove stash
git stash pop

# Clear all stashes
git stash clear

Best Practices

  • ✅ Commit frequently with meaningful messages
  • ✅ Always pull before push
  • ✅ Use branches for features
  • ✅ Review changes before committing
  • ✅ Keep commits atomic (one feature/fix per commit)
  • ⚠️ Never commit sensitive data
  • ⚠️ Avoid large binary files
